aurora hello everybody my name is natalie zawiki i'm a marketing manager here at amazon web services and i'd like to thank you
for joining us today for our introductory webinar i have the pleasure of introducing you to our presenter today
simone brunozzi is a senior technology evangelist with amazon web services and he has been at amazon for about five
years now he has been an evangelist for aws all over the world and is currently based in san francisco
in california and with that i'll hand it over to you summer name thank you very much natalie and aurora
and hello everybody i'm very happy to be here today so what we will do today is to provide
you with a brief introduction to amazon web services or aws as we like to call it and of
course as they already told you you can ask us for questions in the
q a panel and of course at the end of this presentation i will try to answer some of them and
hopefully i will be uh i'll be able to answer the most
common uh questions or or items that you would like to qualify
so let's get started first of all what is amazon web services
so the mission that we have is to enable businesses and developers to use web
services uh what people now call the cloud to build scalable sophisticated reliable and
cost-effective applications and this is something that people are already using all around the
world we have a really huge number of customers now north of the meeting customers we
powered the most popular internet businesses i'm sure that many of you recognize
most of those names airbnb and moto foursquare and netflix instagram dropbox hiraku etc
and we also power many enterprise customers some of them have been recently in the
news we had some events in san francisco and new york recently and some of them were
also presenting on stage with us and i particularly like the stories from nasa or shell or samsung because they
really tell us how the power of cloud computing is enabling them to do things that were not possible before and
just to convince you that we are really big now uh just to give you a quick metric to get a sense each day we
add the equivalent server capacity that used to power amazon.com in 2003
when it was a global 5.2 billion enterprise company so that same amount of server
capacity and storage capacity we add it every day to amazon web services
and we also keep innovating very fast so almost every week there are a few new
services or new features that we announce in fact it's sometimes tough for
evangelists like myself to keep up with the latest and greatest about amazon web services
but let's start by introducing amazon web services now let me try to give you a sense of what we are
talking about um i don't know if you ever heard the term utility computing
in essence by utility computing people mean that you have computing services
compute so virtual servers databases storage lot balancing and other
functions and you use them on demand you pay them as you go
and they're always available for you so whenever you need that capacity you can request that capacity either by using
apis or you can use a management console that we provide on the web so there are easy tools and
visual tools as well as low-level hardcore technical tools for the tech savvy and
we also have a global presence we have many regions around the world
one of them that you see adopted is the govcloud and that one is specific for government agencies in the
us but all the others are available for any customer in any country in the world and when you
sign up for amazon web services you instantly have access to all of those regions worldwide
so for example if you want to launch a web infrastructure in australia or in japan you can do it
immediately there is no need to negotiate other contracts or to talk to a representative the moment you
sign up and you can easily do it online in just a few minutes you have access instant access to this
infrastructure worldwide and every region just to explain what a region is every
region is a set of data centers we divide those data centers logically in what we
call availability zones a question that i usually get asked
is why should a customer know about the availability zone why amazon is
exposing this detail well the reason is by using specific availability zones you
can architect your infrastructure in such a way that you take advantage of
running servers and using storage across multiple data centers and this is a very
important principle in architecting for high availability just to give you a
a better idea and of course we also have edge locations those are end points additional end
points in addition to the data centers and availability zones that we have that you can use to deliver content to
your customers so to give you an idea if you have uh for example the region in
europe and you want to launch ec2 instances those are virtual servers
you can launch them for example in availability zone eu west one a and in availabilities on
eu west 1c those would be physically isolated data centers in our case in this case in
ireland and by using that command there that you see easy to run instances etc there's
there is some technical jargon that essentially says i want to launch this specific type of
machine that one is a linux ami with centos a linux version in it i want to launch
three of them in us sorry in eu west 1a and five of them in ueu west 1c
the ones that are launching uh the a availability zone will be small instance types the other ones will
be medium instance types so you can see that we are already digging into some technical details but
i don't want to scare you all of those things uh if you are tech savvy and if you are familiar with aws
you know exactly what you want to launch you know exactly what type of virtual machines you need etc
but if you are not there is a web interface so a visual interface that allows you to
perform those operations very easily and on the next slide this is an example
where you run machines also across regions in this case we want to launch two additional machines
in two additional availability zones in north virginia and why should a customer do this
because when you run machines across regions you are essentially creating an infrastructure that can span
across the globe and serve customers from the us and from europe or from elsewhere in this case and
another example is that of course you want to authorize a specific port on your web servers in
this case with the easy to authorize api call
and you can also create auto scaling groups those are essentially groups of virtual
servers that automatically scale based on in this case the amount of
cpu traffic that you have on those machines so again this is just to give you an idea
of the completeness of the services that we offer but of
course you don't need to know everything to get started actually getting started is
very easy and as an example in the next slide you can see two screenshots
of the web console you can log in with your credentials and then decide which service you want
to start with for example ec2 which is a service that provides you with virtual servers on demand and then the
screenshot at the bottom right shows you how the ec2 web console
looks like and from here you can simply click and launch an instance or multiple
instances and then get started with your cloud computing infrastructure
so let's uh step away a little bit from those technical details let's try to
understand why customers are interested in using cloud computing and in particular using amazon web
services there are some important benefits the first one is that instead of investing huge amounts of
money up front to purchase infrastructure you can just spin up the capacity that you want
and pay that capacity by the hour or as we say pay as you go this of course brings an
amazing benefit because with on-premises infrastructure you have huge capital investments
you have to deal with physical installation or even if you are using co-location services and you are somehow
detached from the physical infrastructure itself you still deal with the limits of a physical infrastructure on
amazon web services you don't need any investment to get started and you only pay for the
infrastructure that you use and as an example idc analyzing some
customers that are using aws they discovered that on average every
customer replaces 400 servers when moving to the cloud and this is an important
testament of how important how useful custom computing is for those customers
another advantage is economies of scale so since we have a huge global footprint
we have economies of scale and we pass those cost savings to our customers so for
example in the next slide we have some of our use cases samsung they launched
their smart hub application this is essentially a an application that runs on samsung
tvs worldwide and they decided to use amazon web services instead of building
physical infrastructure by doing so they saved 34 million dollars
just at the beginning and they also saved 80 percent of their operational costs
so this was a huge cost saving for samsung a commonwealth bank of australia saved
tens of millions of dollars just by migrating uh a dozen of their internal apps from
on-premises to amazon web services foursquare uses aws for many things
among which analytics and just by moving to aws they reduce their costs
by 50 so those are some examples of how important and useful the adoption of
cloud computing is to enable either existing businesses or new businesses to achieve a lot without spending too
much and another analysis of idc discovered that
there is a 70 lower uh total cost of ownership over the course of five years per app
when you use amazon web services compared to the traditional on premises infrastructure
so this is what happens in reality so economies of scale they bring a lower
variable expense than compared to what companies can achieve themselves
this in turn brings more aws usage because we reduce prices we get more customers
and therefore this drives usage we build additional infrastructure we reach additional economies of scale and then
we keep lowering costs and then bringing those costs to our customers again and in fact
we had more than 30 price reductions since 2006 so in the last five years
sorry in the last seven years since we launched aws and this is a testament of how important
it is for us to continuously win the trust of customers
another important very important benefit is the elastic capacity that you have so you don't need
to guess how much infrastructure how many servers how much storage you need for your
applications or your service because you can just quickly spin up instances whenever you meet
so in a typical scenario traditional infrastructure you have a predicted demand the dotted
line that you see here but then the actual demand can be very different which means you either waste a lot of
capacity that sits there idle or you're not able to provide enough capacity for your
customers and therefore those customers will be very unhappy with your service with cloud computing and amazon web
services you can easily adapt your capacity exactly to your specific needs
and you can also automate this you were seeing before some of the common line interface
instructions to create auto scaling for your capacity but there are of course many other
even simpler ways to do that another advantage is that you have speed
and agility you can spin up instances or use storage in just a few minutes instead of waiting
for weeks for your deployments to be ready and as an example we usually like to
talk about real world examples so real customers lionsgate for example
is a customer that is able to reduce significantly the amount of time
needed to deploy their apps from days or weeks to just a few hours or even
less than that and there are many other examples of customers that vastly reduced their
deployment time just by moving to aws
so speed and agility of course is also very important because sometimes
when you launch a new project or when you are dealing with customers you need to act very quickly let's
imagine that you're launching a marketing campaign and for some reason the marketing campaign is very successful
you need to deploy additional infrastructure very quickly because you want to keep the momentum
going on aws you can spin up that infrastructure in just a few minutes you decide how many machines you need
how big they should be or you just add storage and that's it you don't need to wait the usual call my provider wait for the
physical infrastructure to arrive set up everything etc so it's very fast
and of course on-premises you have millions of dollars invested
in infrastructure while on amazon web services you can experiment with different developer
deployments or different architectures very quickly which means you can also fail quickly and at a low cost for
example if you're trying out a new service or a new design or a new architecture for your
infrastructure you can easily and quickly experiment optionally you can also fail and just recover from that failure
very quickly because you can spin up additional infrastructure destroy the infrastructure you just
created if it's not what you wanted etc so this flexibility this speed and
agility is a very key element of today's cloud infrastructure
another reason why customers are using cloud computing is that you can focus more time on doing your
business instead of focusing in the uh what we call the mac of i.t management or
the undifferentiated heavy lifting so for example we take care of running
data centers providing power cooling cabling machines setting up networking among those
machines uh building racks installing servers installing storage all the labor associated with this
so you don't have to do this by yourself and you can spend that time focusing on your business instead
you can also go global in minutes remember i was showing you a map of our regions let
me actually go to this map now those are regions the stars are the edge locations
you can reach to a global audience in just a few minutes and you can take your application and
deploy that globally in just a few minutes this is an amazing feature imagine
for example facebook games or mobile apps or services that just reach instant
popularity they can quickly scale globally in a few minutes on aws this is something that
was not possible before just to give you an idea of the tale of species that you get
on amazon web services this is amazon.com itself one of the customers of amazon web
services and this is the typical weekly traffic to amazon.com as you can guess a lot of traffic
happens during the day and late at night there is much less traffic but this is actually something that gets
even worse in the month of november where there is a spike in the you know
rush for buying christmas presents and things like that so there is a huge difference between a
normal traditional workload and one you have on a few specific days and as you can guess in a traditional
environment we will need to provision capacity uh at a level like this one the blue line that you see at the top
this will mean that a lot of capacity will be wasted and in our case in the case of
amazon.com this will be approximately 3 4 of the total capacity
that capacity will be just wasted instead amazon.com was completely moved to
amazon web services on november 10 2010 so two and a half years ago now
and that's the date when the last physical web server of amazon.com was turned off
and of course something else was turned on on amazon web services and actually uh
the year after that just uh almost like a year after we also turned off the last web servers
supporting the european business so amazon amazon.be amazon.com.uk amazon.fr
amazon.it the itani one i'm italian so i was particularly proud of this this change and again if you think of
the traffic now you can probably see the blue line that just follows the capacity needs that
amazon.com has that's what happens there is essentially almost no waste of capacity for amazon.com now
that they run on amazon web services and this is another example of a company
called animoto that provides a very simple service you upload your
pictures to uh the website they create a video with effects and
animations based on the music that you want in the in the video and a few years ago they were using
40 50 instances then they launched a facebook app they did some modifications and it went
immediately viral it was featured on techcrunch on slashdot and other sites and
essentially there are a number of ec2 instances grew to a peak of 5 000
instances in just a few days this is an example of the flexibility and elasticity that you can
get when you use amazon web services so now it's time to take a closer look
at some of the web services that we provide i will try to be very quick on this one i want to make
sure we have time for questions but i also want to make sure that i mention at least some of these services
that you should be aware of so typically we have a reference model in which
we divide different services at different levels so the aws
global infrastructure is the physical infrastructure remember the regions and the availability zones and the edge
locations that i mentioned earlier then if we move higher in the stack of course
availability zones are essentially a virtual a mapping of
physical infrastructure and then on top of the lead of the originals
in addition to about this zones we have edge locations which we use to deliver content either static
content or video streaming content to end users and then you can connect to the to this
global infrastructure by using multiple means you can use direct connect which is a dedicated connection
between your it infrastructure and the aws data centers you can use a vpn connection uh either a
hardware vpn connection or a virtual vpn connection to connect
securely to aws you can also use the virtual product
cloud service which is an isolated section of the aws cloud that allows you to launch resources such
as virtual servers or storage or a lot balancers in a virtual network that you define and
you have complete control of the virtual networking environment and the security of this environment as well
and then you can also use route 53 which is a domain name system service
and of course this is a very reliable and cost effective way to have your websites your domain names or
servers to be used on amazon web services and to run on amazon web services
so for example if i have my website let's say uh bernardi.com my personal blog
i can use route53 to route the traffic from anywhere in the world to specific
locations in the amazon web services infrastructure and then serve content for that website but of course
this can be used also for very important production environments or
enterprise use cases then we have the compute services the
main one is called amazon ec2 or elastic compute cloud we offer you different types of machine
instance types small micro medium large extra large and we offer
several services on top of it we give you the ability to import or export
virtual machine images you can monitor those machines you have full control of these machines
essentially what we call administrator rights so you can log in as a route or administrator and perform any
operation of those machines then we have an additional
use case as an example the guardian which is a media company in the uk
uh if you can read on the slide this is from mike bracken the director of technology
development for them it takes less than 10 minutes to set up a new instance on amazon ec2 and maybe another 20 minutes to
connect the infrastructure etc so the lead time is half an hour usually this would take
several weeks to get budget approval and everything else so this is an example how you can
leverage the compute services for uh you know for your infrastructure in this case
you can also take advantage of the auto scaling this is a feature that allows you to decide how when and in what numbers
your ec2 machines should scale over time for example you can say i want a minimum
of two or in this case a four a maximum of 200 machines
and i want them to scale based on a cpu utilization so essentially your infrastructure would
automatically adapt to your specific needs
elastic load balancing is a service that allows you to take incoming traffic and then spread this
traffic across multiple machines possibly served by auto scaling as well
so in especially in the case of customer facing or internet facing businesses
whatever amount of traffic you get from the outside you can use the elastic load balancing to spread
this traffic and then have ec2 machines serve this traffic and eventually scale
if there is a huge demand or spike in traffic
we also have storage the main service the most popular one is s3
is it's a very durable internet storage it offers eleven ninths of the ability
or or as we say ninety nine point nine nine nine nine nine nine nine nine nine percent uh
which in human terms in the more understandable terms it means that if you have one
million files on average you lose one file every 100 000 years so this is the level of
durability that s3 was designed for and there is unlimited storage
the limit is for the single object is five terabytes but there is no limit in the amount of
storage that you use for example a very popular service like dropbox runs entirely on amazon web
services and they were publicly stating in their on their blog a while ago that
they are using several petabytes of storage on amazon s3 and of course s3 has many features many
special services for example you can physically import or export to and from s3 you can set up
automatic object expiry dates to remove old objects after a certain amount of time
etc etc so this is another example spotify which is a very
popular service to listen to songs for free it's a uk-based company
that recently was launched in the us as well so spotify uses s3 very heavily very extensively they
needed a storage solution that could scale very quickly and of course they turned to amazon s3
which is the most mature large-scale product from that point of view and of course
this also helped them expand in the u.s when they added the u.s service as well
we also have virtual block devices we call them elastic block store now the actual
maximum size has been extended to four terabytes just a few days ago and essentially those are virtual drives
that you can mount to instances and then use them with any file system of your choice
and of course the advantage of eds as that's how we call it the elastic block store is that it's
automatically replicated within an availability zone you can probably approximate this as
like having two disk drives in a neighbor raid configuration which
means that if there is one single hardware failure which involves one of your virtual
elastic box stores we actually detect it and then we replace the missing copy
by using the uh the other copy that is still running so there is some redundancy
built in in elastic block store but at the same time there is also an easy way to snapshot
ebs volumes into amazon s3 of course for more durable backups
we also have a cold storage as some people call it a cold storage service which we call a
glacier pressure is a very low cost highly durable
storage service the main difference between glacier and amazon s3 is that on glacier when you store files
on glacier if you need to retrieve those files there is a lead time of a few hours
in order to retrieve the first byte so we essentially give you a much higher
latency in exchange for a much lower cost of storage so this is typically used for archiving
we also have relational database services you can run them on amazon ec2 and
manage them by yourself or you can ask amazon web services to manage those databases for you
and we currently offer oracle databases mysql databases or microsoft sql server databases and
essentially it's very easy to get started by just launching an amazon rds or
relational database service instance and then start using it immediately just after a
few minutes and the database services in this case
rds also has features such as multi-iz az stands for availability zone
and multi-az means that we automatically replicate your database across two
availability zones so you essentially have one master database and one
hot standby replica the exact replica of your main database if anything happens to the main database
the other machine will automatically take over and then start serving customers
and sigra is one of the examples of customers that are taking advantage of this very easy to use feature
dynamodb is what people call a nosql database offering it's a key value
store and it allows you to quickly create a fast and predictable performance
databases that are also fully distributed and also fault tolerant
they run on ssd drives so it's very fast and in fact dynamodb gives you a single
digit millisecond response time whenever you write or read on dynamodb
we also have a queuing service we call it amazon sqs or simple queue service this is uh for
maybe for the tech savvy in the audience this is a very useful service when you want to
orchestrate and send messages across different services in your cloud and this is again a
reliable highly scalable queue service that you don't need to set up you can just use it and pay very little money for
millions of messages in your queues we also have a service called the simple
workflow which allows you to coordinate processing steps across applications
so for example if you have a workflow for example you have one task that
should be followed by another task and then by another task you can essentially create
a workflow with the simple workflow service and then have this specific service
maintain application state across even complex workflows and also track the execution of
individual tasks and as an example on nasa and this is a picture of the mars
rover is using the simple workflow extensively to essentially handle the
different pictures that are taken from the rover left the image and right image they are
warped and then stereo meshed and then out of those pictures they create a 3d map
that is then a tile and this is an example of the several pictures that you get and the result of the essentially the
patching all of those pictures together and all of this is done with the simple workflow
on earth it is not done on space and those are some of the other cool
pictures of the nasa mars rover as well as live pictures that were taken
just a few months ago another application service that is now getting very popular
is cloud search so you might think that search is something very simple but actually when you want to implement
search for your website or for your service or application
there are many features that you might need for search for example faceting or
scamming or synonyms or stop words etc that are very hard to implement by yourself and
again listening to customer feedback as we usually do we created the cloud search service
which allows you to very quickly in just a few clicks to get started and create a search
domain and then use cloud search to provide those features for your search needs
cloudfront is a content delivery service uh remember the little stars on the
globe that i was showing you before those are edge locations so cloudfront allows you to take
any type of content either static content or video content that you want to play in
streaming and then serve this content worldwide to a global audience
by serving content for example to specific edge locations and automatically direct traffic to the
closest edge location so for example if you have a customer that is
in nearby paris the paris edge location will be used to deliver content therefore the
experience for the customer will be of course much better elastic mapreduce
allows you to manage a hardwood cluster automatically and by integrating also amazon s3 for
the storage and dynamodb as well and you can also leverage analytics tools and reportings
to essentially get analytics on the results of your hadoop jobs so for the
non-technical people this is essentially a way to run data intensive applications across
multiple machines in a very easy way elastic bean stock
this is an amazing service and as you see we are moving up in the stack we are now at the
deployment and administration layer so the higher one elastic installed allows you to take
your application either a php or java or python ruby or
net application and just deploy this application on amazon web services
so if you are scared of all of those acronyms and names and if you're scared of the complexity
of using aws if you're just a developer that wants to run
its own application on amazon web services you can just go to elastic bin stock deploy your
application and we take care of creating the infrastructure needed for this application to run
then you can use the cloud formation tool which is a way to create templates of your deployments on amazon
web services and you can use those templates or stacks to repeatedly deploy specific uh
stacks or specific infrastructure even across different regions
and last but not least you can manage identities permissions roles
and essentially the security of your applications of your servers of the access to your aws resources by using the identity and
access management service this gives you very fine-grained control of user rights with aws
so there are many other services that i didn't even mention the aws opsworks is one of the latest
but many others as well so we don't have time to cover all of them just very quickly i will give you
a quick idea of one of the latest that has been recently introduced and this gives you
an idea of the type of innovation that we are bringing in the market so amazon redshift
is a service that allows you to do data warehousing without spending the huge amounts of
money that were typical in this specific vertical so we drastically reduced the cost of running
traditional data warehouses and in fact for example on amazon.com
itself we started a test a while ago in which we compared in premises retail
data warehouse and then we run our test on amazon redshift we're able to have 10x faster
results at a tiny fraction of the cost and
we have an additional service that i want to mention the aws data pipeline it allows you to orchestrate services
for data-driven workflows and they create automated data flows for example
if you have your dynamodb tables and you want to programmatically backup those dynamodb
tables into amazon s3 you can create a data pipeline which gives you a visual tool that allows you
to take the source the destination and the type of operation that you want to perform
and automatically do this on the fly
and again one of the latest services the amazon elastic transcoder as the name implies if you need to transcode videos in
multiple formats or in multiple different types of dimensions or sizes you can do it automatically now
with the amazon elastic transcoder now the number one enterprise
question is usually around security is the cloud secure for my apps and data
we actually take security very seriously
we have a number of certifications and several audit external audit
companies that regularly test our infrastructure and this is essentially a way to tell our
customers your application is very secure on the cloud and we are doing our best
to keep this as our number one priority and as an example uh i want to read just the the quote
on the left from gas hunt the city of the cia you basically turn yourself into a
polymorphic surface to which the attack guy has a much tougher time getting at
that ultimately is the real key advantage to drive security and make things much better for us across the board so
you can imagine that if we can win those type of prices from cia or
government agencies or from big enterprise customers it is uh you know real that we are
focusing a lot on security but then the second enterprise question is how does it work with my on-premise
environ environments so with the existing uh environments that i have and this is
what people sometimes refer to as a hybrid cloud so you can have your corporate data
center it's the figure in the center and then you can easily extend your coupled data center
into the cloud by just adding capacity and connecting those different pieces all together by
using for example vpc or virtual private cloud and then run those applications and also
map those applications into your existing data center even without telling your users that
those applications are partially or totally running in the cloud as well
so we give we provide with private network connections we allow you to migrate workloads in and
out to and from on-premises and cloud environments and we also have several tools that lets
you integrate with existing identity and access control systems as an example
if you are using microsoft active directory for your users
you can easily integrate that with iam in order to authenticate your users to
aws without any intervention or manual customization
so as a summary just to wrap up very quickly those are the main advantages of using
cloud computing you know replacing capital expenditure with variable expense
enjoying economies of scale the elastic capacity and being able to scale
whenever you need the ability to deploy in just a few minutes the ability to focus on your business
without wasting time in undefeated heavy lifting and also the ability to
do global in minutes instead of weeks or months so this is a link for a survey um i
invite you to click on this link later or now to take a survey about this this webinar
and uh this is the last slide this is of course the starting point for you if you want to get to know more about aws
and now we have i think a few minutes for some of the questions thank you very much
thank you so much simone before i hand it over to natalie here i just want to make sure that we do get that survey
launched so i'm going to go ahead and push it out again right now and now i will hand it to natalie to go
through the questions thank you aurora we have got a lot of questions here from people on the line
so i will start with a question here from clinton who asks does amazon offer services to help
companies plan migrate from traditional data centers to aws sure so first of all we have a huge
ecosystem of partners if you go to aws amazon.com you can see there that there
is a section dedicated to our partner network and which means you can find specific
companies that can help you consult etc to help you migrate but we
also have a professional services team which might be useful if you need a much deeper insight into
aws so those are the types of things that we offer and we also have specific services that quickly and
easily help you migrate from traditional data centers to aws
by yourself for example you can move the vmware images from on-premises data
centers to aws you can move the workloads you can move applications
and in on the website on the aws.amazon.com website
there are many sections in the many details in the architecture section
you can just go to ews.amazon.com architecture and that's probably a good
place to start there are some sections that talk specifically about migration
great thank you the next question i have is from alexi and the question is please
elaborate on the security of ec2 instances are there any firewalls available can we
configure them do we need to somehow consider security when we operate an instance
sure so first of all there is a very high level of security by default on ec2
but we also have a security model that we call a shared responsibility model and let me
tell you what this means when you launch an amazon ec2 instance you have full access to this instance so you are
administrator or root on that instance and we don't have access to that instance directly
which means that you are responsible for that instance you're responsible for patching that
machine for regularly updating that machine and if you fail to do so that machine might be attacked
from the external so this is something you have to take care of but at the same time we provide you with
tools and services that make it very easy for you to have a very secure environment in
your on your ec2 machine for example by default we have a firewall for built-in
traffic we call it security groups and by default security groups are
closed on all ports so when you launch an ec2 machine and if you don't know about those
details there is essentially no risk of your machine being accessed by
someone from the outside because there is no port open and then you will have to explicitly
open ports for example if you want to run a web server on that machine you want to open port 80 and if you want
to if it's an apache web server and if you want to open ssh access because you want to manage that machine
you need to open port 22 on the security group for that machine and there is also a
security section on our website you can go to
aws.amazon.com security a better sense of how security
works and what tools you can use and there's also a very expensive white paper that is regularly updated
that tells you all about the security on amazon ec2 and on other services
as well thank you okay the next question i have
here uh is from xke can you speak to how easy or hard it is
to migrate an app from another solution to amazon web services sure so i would say we have to divide it
into two different use cases typically if you have an
application that is built to run on let's say one or more linux servers or
windows server in that case it's incredibly easy to migrate that application to aws
because you can just recreate the same environment on aws and then just deploy your applications
there usually with no change in the application code and maybe some minimal change in the way
the different applications interact together the second example is when instead you have a
legacy application which has a very heavy dependence on a specific hardware or a specific
for example specific operating systems or versions we typically offer most of the operating
systems on the market but if you have a legacy old application written in fortran that runs on a mainframe in that
case for example there is something that you cannot easily port to amazon web services
but what i found uh is that in most cases i would say almost all cases
there is essentially no high barrier in migrating an app from another solution to amazon
web services thank you our next question is from nick
and nick asks as a startup with limited resources we will have to learn aws

and premium support comes in four plans the base plan is free the developer plan
is 49 a month the business plan and the enterprise plan they are uh at the minimum 100 a month
or 400 a month but in particular my suggestion would be when you start
using aws to go for the either the developer plan which is just 49
a month or the business plan which is either 100 a month or 10 percent of your aws bill

you should use no matter if you use aws or not and usually uh there are a few rules i
will just uh i will answer quickly of course the answer could be much longer but briefly the concept is you want to have
independent pieces of your applications they can easily scale independently so essentially you want to
have a loosely coupled system you want those systems to talk together using apis
or using a messaging system for example sqs and the simple workflow that i mentioned
before are two very good components that you can use for that and when you do this it means that you
are designing your application to take advantage of a distributed environment
and when that distributed environment is elastic like in the case of aws it also means
that you can quickly scale the infrastructure that you're using in and out
up and down so you can increase the size of individual machines or you can increase the number of

u.s traffic to a specific lot of balancer in virginia and maybe european traffic
to a lot balancer in ireland but if you use a route 53 you can use a feature called weighted
routing which lets you specify that traffic should be rerouted
to either one of those two or more elastic balancers based on latency from
the customer endpoint so essentially you will obtain the uh the feature of re-routing traffic
